item.title: Commercial Building Inspection Near Overland Park, KS
item.dc:creator: Brit
item.description: Here’s all the essential information to consider before hiring a commercial building inspector in Overland Park, Kansas: company profiles, portfolios, reviews, service areas, sample reports, and more.
item.content:encoded:
Request a Proposal for Commercial Inspection Services

























Commercial Building Inspector Near Overland Park, KS

OVERLAND’S most highly ranked and most reputable inspection company.

Locating a proficient, seasoned, and reliable commercial building inspection team can present difficulties, particularly in instances where a company’s online presence is so insignificant. This predicament motivated us to build a comprehensive and transparent website, designed to furnish prospective clients with meticulously organized details essential for making informed decisions regarding their choice of a commercial building inspector.

Who is Focus Building Inspections?

WE ARE A COMMERCIAL INSPECTION COMPANY FOCUSING SOLELY ON COMMERCIAL PROPERTIES.

Our team is led by Inspector Lance Coffman, who has carved out an excellent reputation as one of Oklahoma's most sought-after commercial property inspectors. Along with his business and life partner, Brit, he has grown a team of reputable inspectors who are highly talented and thoroughly trusted. His integrity and collaboration within the inspection industry have led him into positions of teaching both residential and commercial inspectors at the national level through CCPIA and InterNACHI. He’s also been a guest on Spectora’s podcast several times; Spectora is North America’s leading report-writing software for commercial services. Lance also owns and operates a thriving home inspection business that serves Tulsa, OK, and surrounding counties.

Begin With Our Portfolio Meet Our Team Hear From Our Clients

What Commercial Inspection Services Should You Consider?

We offer a range of commercial inspection services to a variety of clients in OVERLAND PARK, KS.

At our company, we are well-versed in commercial inspections and commercial assessments. We understand that commercial properties are not just assets but also business expenses and income generators. We recognize that many clients require more than a mere building inspection report. That is why we offer professional services that help answer questions about cost-to-cure, maintenance schedules, occupancy, fire safety, evacuation, and more. These records reveal the actual cost of owning the building and provide crucial insights for investors to evaluate the property's value.

Upon receiving each inspection proposal request, we engage in detailed discussions with the client to discern their individual needs and determine the optimal course of action for the prospective building owner.

We take the time to thoroughly understand their specific requirements and concerns, ensuring that our approach aligns perfectly with their goals. This collaborative dialogue allows us to tailor our inspection services to provide the most comprehensive and insightful evaluations possible. By focusing on clear communication and a shared vision, we aim to deliver results that not only meet but exceed our clients' expectations. Our commitment to excellence and client satisfaction is at the forefront of every project we undertake, paving the way for successful and informed decisions for future building owners.

TYPES OF BUILDINGS WE INSPECT in OVERLAND PARK

Office Buildings•Retail Spaces•Industrial & Warehousing Spaces•Multifamily Buildings•Hotels/Motels•Schools & Religious Buildings•Commercial Kitchens & Restaurants•Shopping & Strip Malls

Rigorous Commercial Inspection Standards

CCPIA and ASTM set the standard high - and we meet it every time

When we conduct inspections and write reports, we adhere to the standards and guidelines set forth by CCPIA and ASTM. The Certified Commercial Property Inspectors Association (CCPIA) is a national elite organization that trains and supports dedicated commercial building inspectors. They "enhance the commercial property inspection profession by providing its members with online training and resources for the purpose of professional development and improvement." The American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) is one of the world's largest and most well-established organizations developing international standards for good commercial practices for conducting a baseline Property Condition Assessment (PCA).

item.title: What is the Commercial Building Inspection Process?
item.dc:creator: Brit
item.description: A reputable and professional commercial building inspection company should guide each client through every phase of the inspection process with ease. The client should feel reassured and well-informed at every step.
item.content:encoded:
Request a Proposal for Commercial Inspection Services

What to Expect During a Commercial Building Inspection

How does the process of requesting commercial inspection services work?

The commercial building inspection process is methodical and thorough, aimed at providing the client with a comprehensive understanding of the property's condition and necessary steps for budgeting capital reserve funds and performing maintenance or enhancement. The following steps are a generic guideline outlining a typical commercial building inspection process.

THE CLIENT REQUESTS COMMERCIAL INSPECTION SERVICES

Upon receiving details of the commercial property, the client forwards the information to the commercial inspection firm for assessment. Ideally, the client seeks proposals from various commercial inspection companies to compare services.

CONSULTATION BETWEEN THE CLIENT AND COMMERCIAL INSPECTOR

The inspection company reviews the property information and formulates a tailored commercial inspection proposal. A discussion ensues to address the client's specific requirements and concerns. This dialogue outlines the inspection's scope, areas of interest, and timeline. Should the inspection reveal additional services beneficial to the client, the inspector may propose these.

PRESENTATION OF THE COMMERCIAL INSPECTION PROPOSAL

The client receives the proposal for review. The inspection company remains available to address any queries or uncertainties.

AGREEMENT ON WORK SCOPE, PAYMENT, AND TERMS BETWEEN CLIENT AND INSPECTOR

Upon reviewing and signing the inspection proposal and agreements, the client proceeds to schedule the inspection. Once all necessary documentation is accepted and signed, the inspection is confirmed. If the client declines the proposal, further negotiations are halted.

CONDUCTING THE COMMERCIAL INSPECTION

Subsequently, the inspector meticulously examines the building's structural elements, encompassing the foundation, roofing, walls, windows, and doors, documenting and cataloging data for the client. Mechanical systems such as HVAC, plumbing, and electrical systems are also scrutinized for functionality and compliance with codes and standards. The inspector captures ample photographs on-site to document the findings.

ASSEMBLY OF THE COMMERCIAL INSPECTION REPORT

Following the inspection, a comprehensive report is prepared, summarizing the findings, describing issues or potential concerns in detail, and offering repair recommendations or suggestions for specialist evaluation if necessary. The report is presented to the client in an organized manner, often accompanied by a follow-up meeting or call to discuss the results and address any queries.

REVIEW AND SUBMISSION OF THE COMMERCIAL INSPECTION REPORT BY THE CLIENT

Upon completion, the client is notified that all reports and documents are accessible for review on the inspection portal.

EXIT INTERVIEW BETWEEN CLIENT AND COMMERCIAL INSPECTOR

At the client's discretion, an exit interview can be arranged to review and discuss the findings with the inspector.

A reputable and professional commercial building inspection company should guide each client through every phase of the inspection process with ease. The client should feel reassured and well-informed at every step.

Learn About Our Commercial Inspection Process

How to confidently hire a commercial building inspector.

5 Things You Should Know About Your Commercial Building Inspector

Professional Commercial Inspection Proposal - What to Expect

1. What are the commercial inspector’s professional and educational qualifications?

2. Can the commercial building inspector produce a professional portfolio of work?

3. Does the commercial inspector have proper insurance coverage?

4. Does the commercial inspector have a formal proposal process and require legally binding pre-inspection agreements?

5. Does the commercial inspector have a website that transparently provides important information?

Read the full article here >

Choosing the right commercial inspector involves thorough research and careful consideration of their qualifications, experience, and professionalism. By doing so, you can ensure that you receive a reliable and detailed inspection that will help you make informed decisions about your commercial property.

Focus Building Inspections - Certified Commercial Property Inspectors (CCPIA)

CCPIA and ASTM set the standard high - and we meet it every time

When we conduct inspections and write reports, we adhere to the standards and guidelines set forth by CCPIA and ASTM. The Certified Commercial Property Inspectors Association (CCPIA) is a national elite organization that trains and supports dedicated commercial building inspectors. They "enhance the commercial property inspection profession by providing its members with online training and resources for the purpose of professional development and improvement." The American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) is one of the world's largest and most well-established organizations developing international standards for good commercial practices for conducting a baseline Property Condition Assessment (PCA).

Meet our Lead Commercial Building Inspector!

Our team is led by Inspector Lance Coffman, who has carved out an excellent reputation as one of Oklahoma and it’s surrounding states’ most sought-after commercial property inspectors. Along with his business and life partner, Brit, he has grown a team of reputable inspectors who are highly talented and thoroughly trusted. His integrity and collaboration within the inspection industry have led him into positions of teaching both residential and commercial inspectors at the national level through CCPIA and InterNACHI. He’s also been a guest on Spectora’s podcast several times; Spectora is North America’s leading report-writing software for commercial services. Lance also owns and operates a thriving home inspection business that serves Tulsa, OK, and surrounding counties.

item.title: Does My State Require Certification for Commercial Building Inspectors?
item.dc:creator: Brit
item.description: Believe it or not, there is no certification process to become a commercial building inspector in any state. Because there isn’t a formal agency providing a due diligence process to protect the consumer the consumer must take the correct action to ensure they are hiring a qualified commercial building inspector.
item.content:encoded:
Request a Proposal for Commercial Inspection Services

Commercial Building Inspector’s Certification Process


























Regulations for Commercial Building Inspectors

Believe it or not, there is no certification process to become a commercial building inspector in any state in the United States as of 2024. Because there isn’t a formal agency providing a due diligence process to protect the consumer the consumer must take the correct action to ensure they are hiring a qualified commercial building inspector.

What qualifications should a commercial building inspector have?

Commercial Building Inspectors Are Self-Governed

The quickest way to find a qualified commercial inspector is to search the CCPIA’s database of commercial inspectors. CCPIA stands for Certified Commercial Property Inspector’s Association and is the United States’ leading educational and networking group for commercial inspectors. To join CCPIA an inspector must complete the following actions:

CCPIA Certification Requirements

  1. Join CCPIA as a member.

  2. Complete the Commercial Inspection Standards of Practice Course (online and included with membership).

  3. Complete the Commercial Inspection Code of Ethics Course (online and included with membership).

  4. Pass the Online Commercial Property Inspector Exam (online and included with membership).

(per CCPIA’s website: https://ccpia.org/become-a-certified-commercial-property-inspector/)

Upon completing the above steps the inspector is listed on CCPIA’s database of commercial inspectors relative to the locations they serve, much like Focus Building Inspections’ inspector is listed for Oklahoma, Missouri, Arkansas, and Kansas. Individual inspectors are provided membership to CCPIA upon completing the Online Commercial Property Inspector Exam with a score of 80% or higher and must maintain a continuous membership to be a valid member.

What else should a commercial inspection customer know before hiring a commercial building inspector?

5 Things You Should Know About Your Commercial Building Inspector

1. What are the commercial inspector’s professional and educational qualifications?

Consider asking for any certifications or memberships in professional organizations, which often indicate a commitment to ongoing education and adherence to industry standards.

The most important credential to consider is the inspector’s background and resume. It’s vital to delve into the inspector's background to gauge their expertise and reliability. Typically, a commercial inspector may possess a blend of qualifications, including formal education in residential inspections, engineering, architecture, or construction management. Certifications from recognized organizations such as the American Society of Home Inspectors (ASHI), the International Association of Certified Home Inspectors (InterNACHI), ASTM Property Condition Assessment (PCA), or the International Code Council (ICC) can further solidify their credentials.

Experience is another crucial factor. Some commercial inspectors may have started their careers as structural engineers, bringing a deep understanding of building integrity and safety. Others might have transitioned from residential to commercial inspections, leveraging their detailed knowledge of home inspections to tackle the more complex requirements of commercial buildings. Additionally, those with a background in the construction industry often bring practical, hands-on experience that can be invaluable during inspections.

Ultimately, a qualified commercial inspector should have a well-rounded skill set, combining technical knowledge with practical experience. It’s also beneficial if they stay updated with the latest industry standards and technological advancements, ensuring they can provide the most accurate and comprehensive assessments possible.

2. Can the commercial building inspector produce a professional portfolio of work?











































A seasoned commercial inspector should be able to hand over a professional commercial inspection portfolio as robust proof of their level of expertise and record of experience. An established body of work will confirm the reliability and quality of work the inspector is capable of. Additionally, ensuring that your commercial building inspector has a comprehensive portfolio and solid references will give you greater confidence in their ability to perform a thorough and accurate inspection.

This portfolio should provide specific addressees, and services provided, and ideally include detailed sample reports from previous inspections, highlighting their ability to identify and communicate potential issues. Look for examples that demonstrate their proficiency in various types of commercial properties, such as office buildings, retail spaces, warehouses, multifamily complexes, and industrial facilities.

3. Does the commercial inspector have proper insurance coverage?

It is essential to always confirm the insurance coverage of a commercial inspector. Due to the absence of a state-by-state, or even national, formal credentialing agency, there is no established process for verifying a company or inspector's professional insurance, including a minimum coverage requirement. In some cases, when the commercial inspector holds a residential inspection license the state licensing board will require the home inspector to submit proof of insurance coverage along with their licensing application and ongoing continuing education. Be aware, that residential insurance policies and commercial insurance policies differ, so it’s imperative to minimize your risk by verifying the inspector holds enough insurance coverage for the commercial building you seek to have inspected. A good rule of thumb is that a commercial building inspector’s insurance policy is substantial enough to cover the value and size of the building.

Therefore, it is imperative to request and examine proof of insurance directly from the inspector or company. This precautionary measure ensures your protection in case of any damages or issues that may arise during the inspection. Moreover, consider soliciting references or testimonials from past clients to assess the inspector's dependability and the quality of their services. Adhering to these measures will empower you to make an informed decision, mitigate potential risks, and safeguard your investment.

Lastly, it’s common practice for some commercial inspection companies to subcontract commercial inspectors, so make sure the subcontractor is also insured and the proper entities and persons are listed as additional insured parties.

4. Does the commercial inspector have a formal proposal process and require legally binding pre-inspection agreements?

A truly professional commercial inspector will require written communication between himself and the client as well as legally binding agreements.

Professional Commercial Inspection Proposal - What to Expect

It's important to ensure that all expectations and requirements are clearly outlined and agreed upon before the inspection takes place. This not only protects both parties but also ensures that the inspection process is smooth and efficient.

In addition, a comprehensive pre-inspection agreement will detail the scope of the inspection, the responsibilities of both the inspector and the client, and any limitations or exclusions. This agreement serves as a roadmap for the inspection, helping to prevent misunderstandings and disputes. Insurance companies require commercial building inspectors to use a pre-inspection agreement for every commercial building inspection.

The pre-inspection agreement typically includes:

•Scope of Work: Defines what will be inspected and the methods that will be used.

•Inspection Fee: Outlines the cost of the inspection and any payment terms.

•Responsibilities: Specifies the responsibilities of both the inspector and the client.

•Limitations and Exclusions: Lists any areas or systems that will not be included in the inspection.

•Confidentiality: Ensures that any information gathered during the inspection remains confidential.

•Dispute Resolution: Provides a process for resolving any disputes that may arise from the inspection.

By adhering to a formal proposal process and utilizing pre-inspection agreements, commercial inspectors demonstrate their business competence, commitment to professionalism, and transparency. This practice builds trust with clients and sets the stage for a successful commercial inspection experience.

5. Does the commercial inspector have a website that transparently provides important information?

The commercial inspection company’s website should provide detailed information about the company’s owners, inspection team credentials, offering services, proposal examples, pricing strategies, and more.

Our easy-to-navigate and detailed website walks every client through the process of selecting a commercial building inspector with ease.

Additionally, it would be beneficial if the website featured client testimonials, case studies, and any certifications or affiliations with professional organizations. A robust and thorough FAQ section will also address common concerns and provide clarity on the inspection process. Ensuring that the website is user-friendly, with easy navigation and accessible contact information, can greatly enhance the user experience and build trust with potential clients.

By taking these steps, you ensure that you are hiring a competent and trustworthy commercial building inspector who can provide you with the peace of mind needed when making significant property investments. Ultimately, choosing the right commercial inspector involves thorough research and careful consideration of their qualifications, experience, and professionalism. By doing so, you can ensure that you receive a reliable and detailed inspection that will help you make informed decisions about your commercial property.


What commercial inspection services should you consider?

We offer a range of commercial inspection services to a variety of clients

At our company, we are well-versed in commercial inspections and commercial assessments. We understand that commercial properties are not just assets but also business expenses and income generators. We recognize that many clients require more than a mere building inspection report. That is why we offer professional services that help answer questions about cost-to-cure, maintenance schedules, occupancy, fire safety, evacuation, and more. These records reveal the actual cost of owning the building and provide crucial insights for investors to evaluate the property's value.

Upon receiving each inspection proposal request, we engage in detailed discussions with the client to discern their individual needs and determine the optimal course of action for the prospective building owner.

We take the time to thoroughly understand their specific requirements and concerns, ensuring that our approach aligns perfectly with their goals. This collaborative dialogue allows us to tailor our inspection services to provide the most comprehensive and insightful evaluations possible. By focusing on clear communication and a shared vision, we aim to deliver results that not only meet but exceed our clients' expectations. Our commitment to excellence and client satisfaction is at the forefront of every project we undertake, paving the way for successful and informed decisions for future building owners.

TYPES OF BUILDINGS WE INSPECT

Office Buildings•Retail Spaces•Industrial & Warehousing Spaces•Multifamily Buildings•Hotels/Motels•Schools & Religious Buildings•Commercial Kitchens & Restaurants•Shopping & Strip Malls

 

WE SERVE A VARIETY OF PROFESSIONALS AND ORGANIZATIONS

Commercial Realtors•Commercial Investors•Commercial Lenders•Builders and Construction Managers•Purchasers•Sellers•Building Owners / Business Owners•Tenants / Business Owners•Property Managers•Due Diligence Companies

View Our Inspection Services   View Our Inspection Portfolio

Focus Building Inspections - Certified Commercial Property Inspectors (CCPIA)

CCPIA and ASTM set the standard high - and we meet it every time

When we conduct inspections and write reports, we adhere to the standards and guidelines set forth by CCPIA and ASTM. The Certified Commercial Property Inspectors Association (CCPIA) is a national elite organization that trains and supports dedicated commercial building inspectors. They "enhance the commercial property inspection profession by providing its members with online training and resources for the purpose of professional development and improvement." The American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) is one of the world's largest and most well-established organizations developing international standards for good commercial practices for conducting a baseline Property Condition Assessment (PCA).

Meet our Lead Commercial Building Inspector!

Our team is led by Inspector Lance Coffman, who has carved out an excellent reputation as one of Oklahoma and it’s surrounding states’ most sought-after commercial property inspectors. Along with his business and life partner, Brit, he has grown a team of reputable inspectors who are highly talented and thoroughly trusted. His integrity and collaboration within the inspection industry have led him into positions of teaching both residential and commercial inspectors at the national level through CCPIA and InterNACHI. He’s also been a guest on Spectora’s podcast several times; Spectora is North America’s leading report-writing software for commercial services. Lance also owns and operates a thriving home inspection business that serves Tulsa, OK, and surrounding counties.
